I don't know.
So for people who are new to the series,
to Homefront in general, why is Folkstone important?
Folkstone is this incredible Edwardian resort town
which was also a major military base.
It's the closest place in Britain to the fighting.
So you can hear the war during some of the episodes.
And the really interesting thing about Folkstone is
if you go there now, you recognize it from the series
because it's still got a working harbor.
The barracks are still there, although it's where the gerk is the base now.
And so, in fact, the story just sits rather lightly on top of Folkstone as it is now.
It's been really inspiring as a place to set a drama in.
So did both of you spend time there when you were researching this?
Yeah.
Thinking about the writing, was it inspiring to walk around present day, Folkstone?
Yeah, definitely.
You get excited when you see the street names.
When you've been kind of pouring over a map and saying,
well, we'll put these characters in this street and that's where they'll live.
And we'll make this happen at the Pleasure Gardens Theatre.
And then you kind of wander around it at the beginning
and get to know it at the beginning.
Go away and make up stories.
And then come back and feel quite excited that all these stories are happening in these places
and almost forget that you made them up.
Is it tough to strike a balance between the...
You feel like you have an obligation to some level of historical fact, right?
But then you're making up stories on the other hand.
I think there's a sense of responsibility.
I think if you mention anybody that really existed,
you feel like you must be nice to them if you possibly can.
Because otherwise it's not fair.
Unless you know for a fact that they were horrible.
And then you feel fine about it.
But I think the balance is actually one of the pleasures of the job.
I really... I like the restrictions and the limitations of the history
because it's that classic kind of limitation,
just in relation, phrase that you do in a drama workshop 25 years ago.
But you have these limits and you know
what you can do with them and you know how to write within them.
You can't go anywhere you like.
And that's very useful for narrowing down what you're going to do.
Do you ever feel worried that people are going to call you out on a detail?
Like say, oh, it wasn't like that.

The word choice.
Words we use.

There is.

But the theme is, how will we live when the war ends?
How will we be?
And a sense of its fair for the characters to contemplate the coming of peace
because there are a number of movements towards peace
during the playing out of the season.
And so it's really great for us.
Do you know, they have a sense of the shape of their lives in the four years.
And we have a sense of the shape of the drama in the four years.
And so that understanding of how much we've changed
and how we're going to move forward to a more, I guess, a more democratic future.
That's the general feeling.
That kind of underlines it.
Explain what you mean by that a more democratic future.
I think by the end of the war,
the contribution to national life by the working classes
and by kind of ignored areas of the population couldn't be ignored any longer.
Not only people obviously joining up and fighting,
but an awful lot of women who sort of felled in behind with war work.
And they couldn't be ignored.
And so the representation of the people act is partly about that.
It's partly about recognizing that they have a say in their working out of their lives.
There were some really fantastic sort of moves towards the welfare state.
The recognition that these people are, as they are,
in terms of their health and their education
because they've been ignored and they can't be cast back into obscurity now
that they've played such a role.
Would you recommend that new listeners kind of go ahead and just listen to this season
or would you say, no, go back, go back to episode one?

Okay.
Any episode at all.
You can basically randomly listen until you find something that it's here.
Right, okay.
The same way each episode is told from the point of view of one character.
So that was an incredibly useful decision made really early on.
I think it was actually your daughter's idea.
She's a genius.
I think it was though, she said.
And what it did, it just gave us a kind of boundary with each episode
so that actually we didn't feel like we had to tell everybody's story every time in 12 minutes.
So you could concentrate on one character and the rule was they had to be in every single scene.
And really it had to be their story.
They were important to be peripheral in those scenes,
although sometimes we did cheat, of course.
But it was a great rule actually for each time you felt like you were writing a self-contained play.
And I think with 600 episodes being involved in creating those,
it stopped you from feeling nuts during the process
because on any given day you could sit down with Alice or Kitty or Gabriel
and say, I'm just with them today.
I'll just tell you this story.
These are your actors.
These are the characters.
The character names are good, sorry.
I'm just chucking those names out there.
But you could just sit down with them and not worry about everybody else.
And it was a nice puzzle actually, a nice maths puzzle trying to work out how you could tell.
The stories that we'd sat in a room and developed all together
without any regard for who they would be told through.
And down as an individual writer, it gave you more ownership over your 10 episodes
or however many you were writing.
But there must be a kind of a wild way to write,
because ordinarily we think of stories like a serial story being told kind of in parts.
Generally has a protagonist, like a person who's through whose eyes we see things.
But you're saying it doesn't really work like that.
It doesn't work like that.
We can lurch around and we can skip over some boring bits.
We can go from beat one to beat five, if we want to.
And the other thing which I think is really great about it is you can change the tone from day to day
if you're changing to another character.
You don't have to be as sad as you are at the end of the last episode.
You have to pick up the mood from the end of the previous episode.
You can just say, do you know what?
I just want to write something funny.
The comedy too.
That's great. And I think in a way, this is why I say, you know, just dip in and seek out some good stories.
Each episode does tell a kind of self, there's a self-contained story there.
So that you can just dip in.
But then you could also start to put the pieces together by listening to it.
Eventually you become a cult follower and you become very completist.
But to begin with, it's not frightening.
You've lived and worked with these actors for, I mean, most people who do, if you did a show in the West End or something,
it probably wouldn't last for five years.
And even after a couple of three months, you get pretty attached to people you work with or the characters that you've been playing.
How has that been to realize that this is finishing and that these characters, you're not going to write more scenes with them.
It's just been so awful.
It's been so awful.
And I knew I was going to be sad and then I felt like an idiot when I didn't realize how sad.
Because all summer when we were recording the last season, because we've had a tremendous amount of fun working on this program.
And the team is quite ridiculously funny altogether.
And there's just been a lot of joy in the whole process.
So I just thought that would, I assume stupidly that would carry on right to the bitter end.
And actually it was very difficult to stay cheerful over the summer while we were recording.
Because it was, it just couldn't stop thinking, yeah, but it is over now.
But it is basically over now.
About halfway through a film when I was little I would get start getting sad.
You know, because like, oh no, I'm already halfway through.
I know it really is over now.
And it was like that all summer long ago.
And it really is over now.
And my god, we've just got one more scene to do. It was really sad.
You'll be sad to not be working as closely so often with them.
But there are also these characters that as a writer and as an editor are living in your minds.
Do you find yourself wondering about them or imagining things that they're doing and wishing that you could express that somehow?
Yeah.
I mean, it's a well shaped story.
So the stories have endings.
So their continued existence beyond the story depends on the kind of fiction consumer you are.
There's been kind of mooted. We're not going to do it.
There's been mooted the idea that we skip forward to the second world war and revisit the same characters.
And so you do get this lurch of, oh my god, you know, the children that we've birthed over five years, they're all going to have to fight.
They're all going to be involved.
But of course that's ridiculous because they don't exist.
And we're not going to do it.

Yes.
There is one year later.
Which I'm so glad that's how we did it.

It's been a while.
So you just go detail, detail, detail for, I don't know, like 80% of the book.
And then 20% of the book is, come on, catch up.
All of this has happened since.
And as a way of kind of shaking the story off as well as giving it another ending, it's been really great.
And I think it's the most beautiful play.
And that goes out on the 10th of November.
And we'll also be available as a podcast.

you can start listening and really get into it.
